item.title: Calculus - Differentiation
item.description:
WHY: Why should we learn differentiation?

How to find the speed? How to find the acceleration? - Find the rate: At (when), the rate at which (how) is increasing/decreasing by (what) (unit).

How to sketch a function? - Find the tendency of a function, knowning monotonicity and concavity. (& Optimization)

WHAT: What is differentiation?

$$ \lim_{l \rightarrow x}\frac{f(x) - f(l)}{x - l} \textbf{ #1} = \lim_{\Delta{x} \rightarrow 0}\frac{\Delta{f(x)}}{\Delta{x}} \textbf{ #2} = \frac{df(x)}{dx} \textbf{ #3} \Rightarrow f’(x) \textbf{ #4} $$

Notice. When transform from $\textbf{#2} \rightarrow \textbf{#3}$, we make two changes: Change $\Delta$ to $d$; Leave out $\lim_{\Delta{x} \rightarrow 0}$. So that is a reason why $\frac{df(x)}{dx} \neq df(x) \div dx$, because $f(x)$ and $x$ are not in the same manner, or $\frac{df(x)}{dx}$ is respected to $x$. Thus, it is preferred to write in $\frac{d}{dx}f(x)$, or $f’(x)$ for reminding which is respected.

Difference between differentiation and derivative?

  • $\frac{df(x)}{dx}$ differentiation is a method to crop source function to small range for knowing the tendency
  • $f’(x)$ derivative is that kinds of tendency.

Or we can say, differentiation is a method to find the derivative.

EX-CAL-DIF-01: $g(x) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\Large{\frac{f(x + h) - \frac{3}{4}f(x + 2h) + \frac{1}{8}f(x + 4h) - \frac{3}{8}f(x)}{h^3}}$

WHY: Why a function could be differentiated? - Differentiability

  • Continuous: $\lim_{x \rightarrow a}{f(x)} = f(a)$ ($\lim_{x \rightarrow a}{f(x)} = \lim_{x \rightarrow a^+}{f(x)} = \lim_{x \rightarrow a^-}{f(x)}$)

    • IVT (Intermediate Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is continuous on $[a, b]$, then $\exists c \in [a,b], f(c) \in [f(a), f(b)]$
      • MVT (Mean Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is differentiable on $[a, b]$, then $\exists c, f’(c) = \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}$
      • EVT (Extreme Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is continuous on closed interval $[a, b]$, then $\exists c_1, c_2, f_{max}(x) = f(c_1), f_{min}(x) = f(c_2)$
    • Discontinuous points (Discontinuity)
      • Removable ~: $\lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x) \neq f(a)$
      • Jump ~: $\lim_{x \rightarrow a+}f(x) \neq \lim_{x \rightarrow a-}f(x)$
      • Infinite (Essential) ~: $\lim_{x \rightarrow a^+}f(x)$ or $\lim_{x \rightarrow a^-}f(x)$ equals $\pm \infty$

  • Smooth: $\lim_{c \rightarrow 0^+}{\frac{f(a + c) - f(c)}{c}} = \lim_{c \rightarrow 0^-}{\frac{f(a + c) - f(c)}{c}}$

  • Limit: L’hopital rule

Does EX-CAL-DIF-01 have an easier way to solve?

EX-CAL-DIF-02-01: $\lim_{x \rightarrow \pm\infty}(1 + \frac{1}{x})^x$ (Important one, that’s the definition of $e$)

EX-CAL-DIF-02-02: $\lim_{x \rightarrow 0^+}{x\ln{x}}$, $\lim_{x \rightarrow 0^+}{x^x}$

EX-CAL-DIF-02-03: $\lim_{x \rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin{x} - x}{x(\cos{x} - 1)}$

WHAT: What is the derivative for basic function

$$ \frac{d}{dx}x^n = n \cdot x^{n - 1}, \frac{d}{dx}Constant = 0, \frac{d}{dx}\ln{x} = \frac{1}{x}, \frac{d}{dx}e^x = e^x $$ $$ \frac{d}{dx}\sin{x} = \cos{x}, \frac{d}{dx}\cos{x} = -\sin{x}, \frac{d}{dx}\tan{x} = \frac{1}{\cos^2{x}} = \sec^2{x} $$ $$ \frac{d}{dx}\sin^{-1}{x} = \frac{d}{dx}\arcsin{x} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \frac{d}{dx}\cos^{-1}{x} = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \frac{d}{dx}\tan^{-1}{x} = \frac{1}{1 + x^2} $$

EX-CAL-DIF-03: Try to use definition to derive the first two lines.

HOW: How to differentiate? - Basic rules

$$ \frac{d}{dx}(f(x) + g(x)) = \frac{d}{dx}f(x) + \frac{d}{dx}g(x) \Leftrightarrow (f + g)’ = f’ + g' $$ $$ \frac{d}{dx}(f(x) \cdot g(x)) = \frac{d}{dx}f(x) \cdot g(x) + f(x) \cdot \frac{d}{dx}g(x) \Leftrightarrow (f \cdot g)’ = f’ \cdot g + f \cdot g' $$ $$ \text{Chain rule: } \frac{d}{dx}f(g(x)) = f’(g(x)) \cdot g’(x) = \frac{d}{dg(x)}f(g(x)) \cdot \frac{d}{dx}g(x) $$ $$ \text{Inverse function: }y(x) \Leftrightarrow x(y) \Rightarrow \frac{d}{dx}y(x_1) \cdot \frac{d}{dx}x(y_1) = 1 $$

EX-CAL-DIF-04-01: Try to use the basic rule to derive the third line in WHAT: What is the derivative for basic function

EX-CAL-DIF-04-02: Differentiate $a^x$ and $\log_ax$

EX-CAL-DIF-04-03: Known $x^2 + y^2 = 25$, derive $\frac{d}{dx}y$

HOW: How to apply differentiation in solving problem?

Finding Rates

EX-CAL-DIF-05-01: A particle moves along the x-axis so that at time $t \geq 0$ the position of the particle is given by $x(t) = 0.5t^4 - 1.5t^3 - 2t^2 + 6t - 1$. What is the velocity of the particle at the first instance the particle is at the origin?

EX-CAL-DIF-05-02: The sides and diagonal of the rectangle are strictly increasing with time. At the instant when two sides of rectangle $x = 4$ and $y = 3$, $\frac{d}{dt}x = \frac{d}{dt}z$ and the rate of the diagonal $z$ has $\frac{d}{dt}z = \frac{d}{dt}y$. Derive the value of $k$.

Curve Sketching & Optimization

  • Monotonicity with $dy/dx$
    • Monotonic increasing - $dy/dx > 0$
    • Monotonic decreasing: $dy/dx < 0$
    • Critical point: $f’(x) = 0$ or $\nexists f’(x)$, Stationary point: $f’(x) = 0$, Relative/Local Extrema: $f’(x) = 0$ and $f’’(x) \neq 0$
  • Concavity with $d^2y/dx^2$
    • Concave upward: $d^2y/dx^2 > 0$
    • Concave downward: $d^2y/dx^2 < 0$
    • Inflected point: $f’’(x) = 0$ and $f^{(3)}(x) \neq 0$
